repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:

Checking the extension of a file is done often, e.g. in Nvim's codebase for differentiating Lua and Vimscript files in the runtime. The current way to do this in Lua is (1) a Lua pattern match, which has pitfalls such as not considering filenames starting with a period, or (2) `fnamemodify()` which is both hard to discover and hard to use / read if not very familiar with the possible modifiers.

Solution:

Modeled after Python's pathlib `Path().suffix` property, `vim.fs.suffix()` returns the file extension including the leading period of the extension. Similar to `fnamemodify(file, ":e")` and `Path().suffix` it ignores filenames starting with a period (thus `.git` doesn't result in `git` but `repo.git` does).

Possible follow-up: add `all` option to return all suffixes:
```lua
vim.fs.suffix('repo.tar.gz', { all = true })
-- { '.tar', '.gz' }
```

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -824,4 +824,37 @@ function M.relpath(base, target, opts)
   return vim.startswith(target, base) and target:sub(#base + 1) or nil
 end
 
+--- Return the file's last suffix, if any. The result includes the leading
+--- period.
+---
+--- Example:
+---
+--- ```lua
+--- vim.fs.suffix('vim/fs.lua') -- '.lua'
+--- vim.fs.suffix('~/.git') -- ''
+--- ```
+---
+---@since 13

comment_data.body: Thanks! Was unsure which level it should be indeed ðŸ˜…

comment_data.body: I've modeled this after `vim.fs.basename()`, but I could also return empty string here to simplify the return type. Currently there are three possibilities: `nil` (if the input was `nil`), empty string (no suffix) or suffix.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -824,4 +824,33 @@ function M.relpath(base, target, opts)
   return vim.startswith(target, base) and target:sub(#base + 1) or nil
 end
 
+--- Return the file's last suffix, if any. The result includes the period.
+---
+--- Example:
+---
+--- ```lua
+--- vim.fs.suffix('vim/fs.lua') -- '.lua'
+--- vim.fs.suffix('~/.git') -- ''
+--- ```
+---
+---@since 14
+---@generic T : string|nil
+---@param file T Path
+---@param opts table? Reserved for future use
+---@return T Suffix of {file}
+function M.suffix(file, opts)
+  vim.validate('file', file, 'string', true)
+  vim.validate('opts', opts, 'table', true)
+
+  local base = M.basename(file) --[[@as string?]]
+  if base == nil then
+    return nil
+  end

comment_regular_data.body:
`fnamemodify` is marked as "fast" https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/6af89580555f09c21221c22fb5785124791cd0ac/src/nvim/eval.lua#L2956

so it can be used in the implementation here. We should always lean towards that rather than reimplementing stuff. It also avoids a bunch of duplicate test code, since fnamemodify() is already tested.

Sure. I saw your comment on that matter in `vim.fs.abspath()`. Should I also change it for the other functions (`abspath`, `dirname`, and `basename`)?

FWIW, my implementation is pretty similar to [Python's implementation](https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/16a305f15242ed2acac9bfdbb834804a00f6d9c5/Lib/pathlib/__init__.py#L457-L467) which is also tried and tested.

> Should I also change it for the other functions (`abspath`, `dirname`, and `basename`)?

If possible, though separate PR ideally. Not sure about `abspath`, I think the details were tricky there.

> Similar to `fnamemodify(file, ":e")` and `Path().suffix` it ignores filenames starting with a period (thus `.git` doesn't result in `git` but `repo.git` does).

Why is this desired?

Because there is a general consensus that `.nvimrc` is the filename, _not_ a nameless file  with the `nvimrc` extension. It gives no information about the filetype. 

There are many examples of this in runtine/lua/vim/filetype.lua where those dotfiles are not in the 'extension' part of the vim.filetype.add call but the full filename. It's not a file extension.

> Because there is a general consensus that `.nvimrc` is the filename, _not_ a nameless file with the `nvimrc` extension.

I don't think "the filename" excludes the extension.

> I don't think "the filename" excludes the extension.

Sure, call it the "stem" of the filename. 

Here's an overview of how other stdlibs handle it:

| Language | Function | Output |
|----------|----------|--------|
| Vimscript | `fnamemodify('.nvimrc', ':e')` | `''` |
| Node | `path.extname('.nvimrc')` | `''` |
| Ruby | `File.extname('.nvimrc')` | `''` |
| Python | `Path('.nvimrc').suffix` | `''` |
| PHP | `pathinfo(".nvimrc", PATHINFO_EXTENSION)` | `'.nvimrc'` |
| Go | `filepath.Ext(".nvimrc")` | `'.nvimrc'` |
| Rust | `Path::new(".nvimrc").extension()` | `None` |
| Swift | `URL(fileURLWithPath: ".nvimrc").pathExtension` | `''` |
| Kotlin | `File(".nvimrc").extension` | `'nvimrc'` |
| C++ | `std::filesystem::path(".nvimrc").extension()` | `""` |
| Julia | `splitext(".nvimrc")[2]` | `''` |
| Zig | `std.fs.path.extension(".nvimrc")` | No output |
why do not just using `vim.fn.fnamemodify(file, ':e')`, What's the point of adding such wraps besides making the code execute a few more lines.

> why do not just using vim.fn.fnamemodify(file, ':e'), What's the point of adding such wraps besides making the code execute a few more lines.

It's all about the ergonomics of consuming the Nvim interface.

A major advantage of the Lua stdlib is that Nvim's interface can improve without breaking the existing Vimscript interface. The Lua interface is more user friendly, largely because of Lua itself as language, enabling features such as proper namespacing and optional dictionary arguments. This allows for a more modern approach to designing a standard library.

Currently, the stdlib is somewhere in between having only half of functionality. The distinctions between `vim.*`, `vim.api`, `vim.cmd`, and `vim.fn` are clear to users with Vim experience, but they are confusing to newcomers, and I have seen people struggle to understand that difference. Having an `fs` module that only implements part of the functionality one would expect, while related functionality lives in `vim.fn.*` and behaves differently, reduces overall ergonomics rather than improving it. Another advantage of moving this interface into Lua is that the implementation can be changed later on if necessary (so not wrapping `fnamemodify` anymore). Lifting functionality to Lua definitionally fits multiple [goals of the project](https://neovim.io/charter/).

We already have `abspath()`, `basename()`, and `dirname()` in `vim.fs`. A great interface is one where you can guess the function name based on the functionality you need. Not one where you have to endlessly search through the docs to find out that the function you need is _actually a Vimscript function_ (implementation detail) and defined elsewhere.

title: vim.fs.suffix() returns file extension
